Dear Milt

I think there is a name --- machi-okuri.  :)

So just wondering if a small hagiri under the habaki is the reason
that blades become machi-okuri.

later
david

 Re: Jersey City sword show...  question for Gordon ( again )
Posted by: "bungotakadasword" MuramasaIII@...   bungotakadasword
Sat Sep 16, 2006 9:23 pm (PST)
--- In nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com, Gordon Robson <robsongo@...> wrote:
 >
 > Had a good time. Enjoyed seeing lots of familiar faces and some good
 > swords. People are still submitting stuff they shouldn't, however. I
 > do hope the level of study continues to improve. A lot of the guys
 > who have been with this for some time now did very well with some
 > only getting one or two rejections.

 >Gordon,
 >to avoid submitting stuff i shouldn't, have a question for
 >you...........

 >If the " hagiri " appears right below the hamachi, by definition it is
 >not a " hagiri " since it is located on the nakago, yes ?

 >So if I have a sword with hagiri ( hidden under the habaki ), just
 >above the hamachi, and if I have Big Mo " reshape the nakago just a
 >little and also " move up " the hamachi.........wella, no more hagiri ??

 >Would the shinsa team pinkie it just because there's a nakagogiri ( the
 >term doesn't exist, I check the books........ =) )?

 >Not that I would submit this as you promise previously a special pink
 >sheet for me..........just curious.

 >Milt
